conversion.label: Hexadecimal (Text → Hex)
conversion.description: Encode the text as hexadecimal bytes (UTF-8).
conversion.details: This is an encoding method that consist of numbers 0-9 and letters A-F for representing numerical values using base 16 which is like base 10 except that you have 16 fingers.

conversion.label: Binary (Text → Binary)
conversion.description: Represent each byte of the text as 8-bit binary.
conversion.details: This is an encoding method that consists of 1s and 0s to represent base 2 which is like base 16 if you lost 8 fingers.

conversion.label: Base64 Encoding
conversion.details: An encoding method that consists of 64 safe, printable ASCII characters: (A-Z, a-z, 0-9, +, /, and = for padding) for representing binary data using base 64. This is a way to translate computer data into text you can safely copy and paste anywhere on the internet without corruption.

conversion.label: URL Encoding
conversion.description: AKA Percent-encoding. Encode characters so the string can be safely used in a URL.
conversion.details: This is an encoding method that consists of a restricted set of safe ASCII characters for representing data within a Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) using base 256 (basically all possible bytes) while translating unsafe characters into a percent-sign followed by their two-digit hexadecimal.

conversion.label: Hashing (MD5)
conversion.description: Compute the MD5 hash of the text.
conversion.details: A Hashing method that takes an input of any size and uses a complex mathematical algorithm to generate a unique, fixed-length "digital fingerprint." The output will always be a 32-char hexadecimal string.

conversion.label: Hashing (SHA-1)
conversion.description: Compute the SHA-1 hash of the text.
conversion.details: A Hashing method that is similar to MD5 but always produces a 40-char hexadecimal string that is a bit longer and lsightly more complex than the 32-char MD5 hash. Because it is longer, it is less more collision-resistant (ie two unrelated files should not have the same SHA-1 hash)

conversion.label: Hashing (SHA-256)
conversion.description: Compute the SHA-256 hash of the text.
conversion.details: Another Hashing method that is similar to MD5 and belongs to the SHA-2 family of algorithms. The output for this is a 64-char hexadecimal string. Widely used and trusted in various fields such as security systems to crytpocurrency networks for its high resistance to collision attacks.

conversion.label: Octet (Text → Decimal Bytes)
conversion.description: Show each byte of the text as a decimal number (0–255).
conversion.details: A unit of digital information that is precisely and exactly eight bits or exactly two nybbles.
